{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3714208,"name":"brrian27","username":"brrian27","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/aca169/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-14T19:15:32.066Z","cooked":"

For my capstone project in the Design Science Master’s program at the University of Michigan, I planned curriculum for and hosted off-season workshops about design process for team 7660 (the Byting Irish). These workshops were intended to address the team’s self-identified weakness of trying to do too much with our robot designs.

Workshop Content & Slides

We had eight different workshops on the following topics:

  • Strategic Design
  • Ideation
  • Secondary Research
  • Prototyping
  • Decision-Making in Design
  • Human-Centered Design
  • FRC Strategy
  • Design Process

The workshop content is intended to help students improve their design practices in FRC and in the future real-world engineering/design activities. Most sessions included real-world examples and activities. There are many examples related to companies in our state (Michigan).

You can view public versions of the slides for each session here. Please feel free to modify these and use them with your team.

Design Process

The workshops culminated in the development of a design process for our team to implement during the next season. The structure of this process is based on the popular double diamond
design model. The full process model is shown below and in a pdf here.

FRC Design Process1395×784 48.6 KB

Understand the Game & Prioritize Functions1395×782 40.4 KB

Explore Ideas & Evaluate Ideas1392×782 45.2 KB

Deliver Features1398×782 64.5 KB

I have really enjoyed working on this project with my team. I hope that we can continue to refine this process and use it to make a successful design next season. Considering design process is essential for any engineering project, including FRC. I hope that these resources will be helpful to other teams.

If you have any questions or comments, please let me know. I have also written a larger report about the project for my degree, and I’d be happy to share it with anyone who is interested.
